plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: Oleander is a hardy evergreen shrub that produces clusters of fragrant, funnel-shaped flowers. It thrives in Mediterranean climates and blooms profusely in late autumn and early winter in warm regions.
plants.location: Mediterranean Basin, Southern United States, and tropical to subtropical regions worldwide
plants.funFact: All parts of oleander are toxic if ingested, yet it's widely grown for its long-lasting blooms and drought tolerance.

plants.name: Eucalyptus pauciflora
plants.description: Snow Gum is a species of eucalyptus native to high-altitude regions of southeastern Australia. It often flowers in early summer and again sporadically through winter, featuring creamy white flowers.
plants.bloomingSeason: December to February and sometimes in winter
plants.funFact: Snow Gum's bark peels in colorful ribbons, and it is one of the few trees flowering in winter in its native alpine habitat.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: Camellias are evergreen shrubs known for their large, rose-like flowers. Many cultivars bloom from late fall through winter, thriving in temperate climates.
plants.location: East Asia, cultivated worldwide in gardens for winter blooms
plants.funFact: Camellia flowers are edible and occasionally used to garnish dishes in East Asia.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A perennial herbaceous plant found in Europe, the Christmas Rose blooms in winter, often around Christmas time. It has striking white flowers that can tolerate frost.
plants.location: Central and Southern Europe, especially in mountainous regions
plants.funFact: Despite its name, Christmas Rose is not a rose but a member of the buttercup family (Ranunculaceae).
